September 11, 1961
Mr. William G. Harley
NAEB
DuPont Circle Office Bldg.
1346 Connecticut Ave., N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
Dear Bill:
Please excuse the delay in responding to your letter and the
brevity of this response. 1 just returned to town to find your letter
here — along with a large pile of other business to attend to. I am
trying to do all of this hastily because I will only be in town for
two days before leaving for another week to teach at an ICA seminar
in Michigan.
I believe that your idea is a fine one. It seems to me that
this is something which the NAEB could do quite readily, if it got the
right person in as director in Washington. It ought to be someone who
has had survey experience, not merely any sort of research experience.
A prime candidate is Harrison Summers at Ohio State who has been doing
surveys for many years. He is due for retirement there before too long
and might jump at the chance to do something of this sort. Forest Whan
at Kansas State has also had a great deal of experience at this sort of
thing. In the yearly statewide radio and television surveys which he
ran for many years in Iowa and Kansas and elsewhere he used student inter¬
viewers and faculty supervisors in each area. The only problem with Forest
is that he would come rather high salary-wise I would guess. However, you
might get more takers since he has quite a reputation among commercial
broadcasters. I would think that interview schedules and other procedures
could be standardized so that the project would not be too dependent upon
regional research directors, not all of whom would nave had great experi¬
ence at survey work.
I would guess that your budget is far too low, unless the $30,000
does not include the cost of any of the surveys. You will find that you
will need to pay both your local supervisors and the student interviewers.
Otherwise, it is almost impossible to get dependable work done. (Even
when you pay students for this sort of thing, someone will need to keep
after them very carefully. Again, this would be the kind of thing with
which Whan has had much experience. He probably ought to be brought in
as a consultant in setting it up whether he becomes the director or not.)
